thread.section_title: Political News - International and UK Politics | Sky News
thread.title: Charlotte Church Sorry After 'Scum' Protest

author: news.sky
title: Charlotte Church Sorry After 'Scum' Protest
text:
Charlotte Church is to write an open letter apologising for the behaviour of some anti-austerity protesters who spat at people attending the Conservative Party conference. The singer and anti-austerity activist condemned demonstrators who shouted "scum" at MPs, party members, journalists, lobbyists and staff as they arrived at the opening day of the event in Manchester.
Ms Church said: "I would never call anybody scum. I think it's fundamentally unhelpful in the issues that we are trying to talk about.
"Name calling is never a good thing. These are tiny instances which have happened in tens of thousands of people. 
"Whoever the person that got spat in the face I'm sure it was a horrible experience.
Play video "'PM Should Live On Benefits'" Video: 'PM Should Live On Benefits' "I plan to write an open letter on behalf of the majority of people who were protesting, just to say we are really sorry and this is not what it is about, to represent the rest of the people who were there who would never act like that."
Her comments come after Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn was criticised by one of his most senior shadow ministers for taking part in the protests.
Shadow Europe minister Pat McFadden, who served as a minister under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, accused Mr Corbyn of turning Labour into a protest movement.
Play video "Corbyn Has Right To Protest" Video: Corbyn Has Right To Protest Interviewed on the Murnaghan programme on Sky News, Mr McFadden said now that Mr Corbyn was Labour leader he had to change from a politician of protest into one potentially of government.
